channel.title: 317 (winterLove): Requesting help to understand "stream.java"

item.title: 317 (winterLove): Requesting help to understand "stream.java"
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Ole Kristian, post:11, topic:544867”][quote]
you seem eager to learn more so why not do it on a server like runesource? its simple, and you’ll actually learn somewhat good programming habits. plus you’ll also learn about how NIO works which is essentially what every runescape server that isn’t from 2007 uses lol
[/quote]

“stream” is a really horrible buffer implementation by the way

Thanks, lare69!
I will have a look at runesource.
Do you know where I can learn more about protocol buffers?
I have tried to search for it on Google and on YouTube, but what is represented are either buffers to store pictures for rendering on the screen, or file I/O.[/quote]
there’s nothing more you really need to know about a buffer… its basically a container for data of a specific primitive type, in this case bytes. for example, if you need to mail something to your friend, you package it and ship it off. then your friend can ship something back to you.

same thing for rsps, you put whatever data needs to be sent to the client inside a buffer and send it off to the client using the socket channel (outgoing packets: sending a message, sending hint icons, opening an interface, etc.)

the client can then send data back the same way (incoming packets: equipping an item, picking up an item, clicking an object, clicking an npc, etc.)

[quote=“RandQm, post:12, topic:544867”][quote author=lare69 link=topic=663744.msg4436219#msg4436219 date=1405133363]

It has nothing to do with java, it has to do with networking.

lol what…
[/quote]
You think java is the only language that supports networking or what?[/quote]
obviously not but he’s referring to networking using java so it does have something to do with java lol

Read full topic

item.title: 317 (winterLove): Requesting help to understand "stream.java"
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

RandQm:

It has nothing to do with java, it has to do with networking.

lol what…

@op: its a buffer, buffers are used to write data to and receive data from the client. the day you realize that the way runescape servers work is simply by communicating with the client, is the day you’ll just “get it”.

“stream” is a really horrible buffer implementation by the way

you seem eager to learn more so why not do it on a server like runesource? its simple, and you’ll actually learn somewhat good programming habits. plus you’ll also learn about how NIO works which is essentially what every runescape server that isn’t from 2007 uses lol

Read full topic

item.title: 317 (winterLove): Requesting help to understand "stream.java"
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“Ole Kristian, post:3, topic:544867”][quote]
It’s pretty advanced, I wouldn’t bother if you’re pretty new.
It’s for the network stream, the actual bits and bytes that are send through your cables to the client and back.
The streams handle that data.
[/quote]

Hmmm… Yes, I understand that it’s network I/O, but I don’t know what it’s called in Java and I don’t know how to look it up, as I don’t know what to search for.
I have deciffered the code from Server.java’s main-method, further to the PlayerHandler’s deligation of Player-instance slot and now I’m this far. :([/quote]

It has nothing to do with java, it has to do with networking.
The stream class methods are used to create frames and packets so we can communicate over the network.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model

RSPS related, every client will have a connection with the server.
The communication between those happens via network streams, so every player will both client and server sided have a stream
that reads or writes data.

When we e.g. use stream.writeByte(); we send a byte to the client/server.
stream.createFrame(26) will obviously created a frame.
And when we combine those we can create packets.
again: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model

Read full topic

item.title: 317 (winterLove): Requesting help to understand "stream.java"
item.dc:creator: @Ole_Kristian Ole Kristian
item.description:
@Ole_Kristian wrote:

Hello!
I am working on a 317 RSPS-project.
The base I am using is a winterLove-base and I am confused by it’s
stream-class and a bit of code in the Client-class’ constructor.

I’m sure I got this problem because I don’t know this part of Java, but I don’t know what information I should search for to learn it.
Could someone please tell me or give me some hints on what I should be reading/watching?

Here’s a copy of the code confusing me at the Client-class’ constructor:

outStream = new stream(new byte[bufferSize]);
outStream.currentOffset = 0;
inStream = new stream(new byte[bufferSize]);
inStream.currentOffset = 0;

readPtr = writePtr = 0;
buffer = buffer = new byte[bufferSize];

Thanks! Have a nice day.

Read full topic
